generated_text: The structure of ice II, which is the most stable phase of water at high pressure, has been the subject of intense research for decades. However, the structure of the hydrate phase, which is the most stable phase of water at high pressure, has not been resolved. Here, we report the structure of the hydrate phase of water at high pressure and temperature.

We show that the category of Hilbert spaces and linear operators has an initial object, which is the space of complex-valued functions on the real line. This provides a categorical foundation for quantum theory in terms of the language of category theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we report the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two species of myxozoans, which are sister to a cnidarian parasite, and compare these to the genome of a cnidarian parasite. Our results provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite.

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is one of the most important factors that determine the pathogenicity of a virus. In this study, we show that the accessory protein Orf6 of SARS-CoV-2, which is essential for viral replication, is able to block nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for induction of IFN-stimulated genes. Our data reveal a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may help in the development of new strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the proton channel, the voltage-gated H+ channel (Hv1). We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to grow to 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. This study shows that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the future, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase in the major maize-exporting countries. These results highlight the importance of breeding for heat tolerance, as well as the need for investments in adaptation strategies, to ensure food security in the future.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of wild and domestic LMH in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, LMH consumed different plant species, and that dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of LMH in ecosystem functioning and biodiversity conservation.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Many businesses plan to seek funding through the CARES Act, but many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, and that most of it is concentrated in convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. This distribution is mostly due to the selective removal of millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic by a combination of processes yet to be discovered. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of the missing plastic debris, and of the importance of the size distribution of floating plastic debris. It also provides a new perspective on the distribution of floating debris in the ocean, and on the importance of the size distribution of floating debris.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in science. The solar system is thought to have formed from the aggregation of dust particles in the interstellar medium. However, the formation of the solar system is still a mystery. We determined the age of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of <300 Ma and >1 Ga, which is shorter than the expected lifetime of the grains in the interstellar medium.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has increased exponentially. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide energy to offspring correlates with increased reproductive output. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is not due to an increase in resource availability, but rather an increase in metabolic power. This suggests that the ability to provide energy to offspring is a key factor in determining reproductive output.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in the brain of a mouse model of MSA. This suggests that VX-765 could be a promising drug for the treatment of MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It is the primary regulator of vascular function and is the target of many diseases. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to respond to a wide variety of stimuli and to integrate information from multiple sources. This paper describes the nature of the communication network between endothelial cells and the properties of the network that are important for the endothelium to function properly. The findings are important for understanding the endothelium and its role in health and disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health surveillance and epidemiological modeling. We describe the design and operation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers and policy makers in their efforts to understand and respond to the pandemic.

The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the pore of K+ channels, and it is the site of ion conduction. The selectivity filter is also the site of allosteric communication between the activation gate and the inactivation gate. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the structural coupling between the activation gate and the inactivation gate.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host and the environment. The role of the gut microbiome in the health of the host is not fully understood, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the diet of the host. This study shows that anaerobic fungi, which are a minor component of the gut microbiome, synthesize a variety of natural products that could be used by the host to influence the composition of the microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, yet the influence of personality traits on social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social behavior and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. The ability to design and fabricate mechanical devices with desired behaviors is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis approach that can design and fabricate composite structures with multiple material phases to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The structures are digitally synthesized with organic shapes and motions, and the corresponding behaviors are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general framework for the design of mechanical devices with desired behaviors. It also demonstrates the potential of the digital design and fabrication of mechanical devices with complex and organic shapes and behaviors. This work is expected to inspire the design of mechanical devices with desired behaviors in the future.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development and differentiation in vertebrates. In humans, the hemoglobin system is regulated by the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) in erythroid cells. Here we show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in human fetal liver and adult bone marrow, and that it is involved in the regulation of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid cells.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of resistance to current cancer therapies is a major obstacle to successful treatment. In this study, we identified a mechanism of cancer cell resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, and developed a strategy for overcoming this resistance. Our findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway in combination with ferroptosis induction may be a promising approach for the treatment of cancer. This strategy may be applicable to other cancer types with similar mechanisms of resistance to ferroptosis. These findings may also have implications for the development of new models of ferroptosis and ferroptosis-based therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is associated with the up-regulation of the Ca2+ sensor protein STIM1. Our findings suggest that the use of LCCBs should be limited in patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study also provides a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of hypertension. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations associated with early-seral forests, but not older forests. We also show that the NWFP failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, which are now accelerating. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and the need to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The predicted best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. We believe that this work will contribute to the development of new antibiotics and will help to address the global health problem of antibiotic resistance. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, and the networks are difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of the impact of environmental change on biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We show that the evolution of the species flock is linked to the evolution of the climate system, and that the lake underwent large-scale changes in hydroclimate and lake level over the last 1.3 My.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly, but the impact of this on sleep is unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device suppresses melatonin, reduces sleepiness, and phase-delays the circadian clock, all of which may have important implications for performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event that has been attributed to a bolide impact. However, the impact hypothesis has been challenged by the lack of evidence for a bolide impact in the form of a meteorite or its parent body. Here, we show that the Younger Dryas cooling is likely due to a terrestrial source, such as a bolide impact, and that the impact was in northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is still to be determined. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice results in spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, in contrast to congenital deficiency, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. Notably, cell transfer of thymocytes de novo produced myocarditis, otherwise not observed in donor mice depleted in adulthood. Moreover, CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Our analyses resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, these novel genes triggered adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding PCWDEs.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of new antibody-based therapeutics to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. (Read more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results suggest that the size of the population may be more important for the maintenance of diversity than for the enhancement of performance.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and is the sixth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is thought to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be two-step, with the first step being the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron, which is metastable at core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and its anisotropy. They also suggest that the bcc phase may be the dominant phase in the core of other planets. This study may also have implications for the formation of the solar system and the origin of the universe. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that the brain responses to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), are attenuated in marijuana abusers, who also show increased stress reactivity and irritability. These findings suggest that the attenuated brain responses to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s processing of it is a central focus of neuroscience. However, the brain’s language system is not a single structure or process, but rather a set of interacting mechanisms. Here, we show that deep learning models that have been trained on large language datasets can predict a wide range of brain and behavioral measures of language processing. This suggests that the language system in the brain is predictive, and that the models’ ability to predict the next word in a sentence is related to their ability to predict brain activity and behavior. These results provide computational support for the existence of a language system in the brain, and suggest that it is predictive.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it is still in its infancy. It is now entering scientific computing with full force. However, there is a paradox: Even though there are many well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), there does not exist any algorithm that can train (or compute) such a NN. We address this paradox by showing that the instability of DL is due to the fact that current DL methods typically use a single algorithm, stochastic gradient descent, which is unstable in well-conditioned problems. We introduce a new algorithm, fast iterative restarted networks, which we prove and numerically verify to be stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the well-conditioned problem. Our results provide a classification theory of stability for neural networks. They also provide a new algorithm for solving well-conditioned problems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act in time, the failure of the medical system to cope, and the failure of people to follow the rules. One of the most prominent explanations for the latter is that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This paper shows that this explanation is based on a flawed experiment, which was published 45 years ago. The paper discusses the implications of this for the study of human behavior and the design of experiments.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and the cause of the disease has been debated for even longer. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a patient with lepromatous leprosy and compared it with that of the causative agent of leprosy, Mycobacterium leprae. We found that the two organisms are remarkably conserved, despite their ancient separation, and that they are still capable of causing similar diseases. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of the leprosy pathogen and the evolution of the disease itself. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of entanglement in quantum many-body systems is a fundamental question of quantum science. It is also a challenging problem, as it is usually impossible to compute the exact dynamics. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is a regime that is accessible to numerical simulations. We provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain, which is integrable and thus allows for a complete analytical treatment. Our results provide a general framework for the entanglement dynamics in integrable quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that requires a rapid and large-scale development of a safe and effective vaccine. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain. This vaccine candidate is expected to be safe and effective in a large number of people, and it can be manufactured at large scale.

The Second Pandemic of plague, caused by Yersinia pestis, occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries. The disease was responsible for high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common assumption being that rats were the primary vectors. Here, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which is able to fit mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human-to-human transmission in the spread of infectious diseases.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most important and fascinating aspects of animal biology. It is also one of the most difficult to study because of the large size of the organ. This study shows that the evolution of the brain is not only about increasing the size of the organ but also about increasing the number of neurons. The study also shows that the evolution of the brain is not a linear process but rather a series of steps, each of which is unique to a particular group of animals.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been the subject of intense investigation, but the results have been mixed. We have found that TRAP1 is required for the survival of tumor cells, and that it promotes tumor cell invasiveness. These findings suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, the mechanism by which it does so is unknown. Here, we show that ADF can induce a torque on the filaments it binds to, and that this torque enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to the function of ADF, as it allows it to sever highly connected filament networks, such as those found in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in the food supply and is known to be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that the ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and for the design of interventions to reduce the consumption of fructose-sweetened beverages.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island and found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in the population. Finally, we found that the genetic structure is not only a function of the admixture, but also of the geography, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a highly heterogeneous way.

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others in a large social network. This is a major finding, because it suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others without their awareness. This is a major finding, because it suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others without their awareness. It also suggests that people’s emotions are malleable, and that people can be influenced to experience positive emotions even when they are not feeling positive. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for the design of social networks, and for the design of social interventions. It also suggests that people’s emotions are malleable, and that people can be influenced to experience positive emotions even when they are not feeling positive.

The vast majority of RNA in the cell is not protein-coding, and the structure and function of noncoding RNAs are key determinants of cell identity and function. Chemical modifications of RNA are a key mechanism by which the structure and function of RNAs can be regulated. Here, we show that the presence of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can have a significant impact on the rate of protein synthesis. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This finding has implications for the function of Ψ in the cell, and suggests that the ribosome encountering Ψ can be a source of error in translation. This may have implications for the function of Ψ in the cell, and may also have implications for the function of Ψ in the cell, and may also have implications for the function of Ψ in the cell.

This study shows that feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and well-being, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust to the effects of factors such as socioeconomic status, education, and sex. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of aquatic life has been a major driver of the diversification of mammals, but the extent to which this has been the case has been difficult to test quantitatively. Here, we show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving mammals toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This size attractor is consistent with the energetic demands of the aquatic environment, which are constraining the evolution of mammals toward larger body sizes.

The common cold is one of the most common and widespread diseases in the world, and rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. Rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. Here, we show that rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of rhinovirus vaccines and therapeutics.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in their surroundings. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces and to regulate its virulence. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing is distinct from the classical chemosensory systems used by bacteria, and may be a general mechanism used by bacteria to sense their environment.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the number of pesticides is constantly increasing. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface water and the risk of exceeding the legally accepted regulatory threshold levels. The results show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is a major threat to the quality of global surface water resources.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, and the identification of multiple human and deer lineages. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study highlights the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the impacts of these dams, and the solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, which are toxic to neurons. However, the earliest events in AD pathogenesis are not known, and the role of the immune system in the development of AD is poorly understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ is the primary toxic species that triggers an immune response in neurons, which in turn, activates microglia and initiates the inflammatory cascade. These findings provide a molecular basis for the role of the immune system in AD, and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies.

The domestic chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens remains elusive. Here we present evidence from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was practiced as early as the fourth century B.C.E. This is the earliest known evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the world.

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. The results reported here provide evidence that the folding of a large protein proceeds through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this occurs is not fully understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 to accumulate to high levels. We also show that the enzyme responsible for removing capped RNA, RppH, is activated by disulfide stress and plays a major role in decapping Np4-capped RNA. This work provides insight into the role of Np4 in stress response and the mechanism by which the decapping of capped RNA is regulated. It also provides a model for the role of decapping in the regulation of gene expression. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high rate of mortality. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main mechanisms involved in the development of sepsis-induced immunosuppression are still unknown. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore immune function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing sepsis-induced Treg and MDSC expansion. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a new therapeutic strategy for sepsis. (PsycINFO Database Record

The biomass of the biosphere is the sum of the masses of all living organisms. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. Here, we provide a census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life, establishing a global view of the distribution of biomass among the different taxa. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly concentrated in the ocean. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the distribution of biomass among the different taxa.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon that has been observed in a variety of physical, biological, and social systems. SOC systems are characterized by the fact that their dynamics are self-sustaining, in the sense that the system is able to maintain a state of criticality, and that the dynamics of the system are such that the probability of a large event occurring is proportional to the time since the last event. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronic and quantum applications. However, it is not easy to control its properties, especially its bandgap, which is a key parameter for applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly through strain engineering, which can be used to control its bandgap. This work provides a new route to control the bandgap of diamond, which is of great importance for its applications. It also provides a new paradigm for exploring the relationship between the bandstructure and the elastic properties of solids. This work can also be extended to other wide-bandgap materials.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. The study of the structure and function of peptides in plants is even more interesting, as they are the first line of defense against pathogens.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and demonstrate that the female reproductive tract is a major contributor to the sperm proteome. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and demonstrates that the female reproductive tract is a major contributor to the sperm proteome. This work expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. Our findings may also have implications for the study of other species and may be relevant to the study of human reproduction.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. The binding of VWF to GPIbα is important for hemostasis. We show that force can switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for the activation of VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a disorder of VWF function.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of microorganisms that has been shown to influence human health. However, the human-associated viruses have been difficult to study, and the field has been hindered by a lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a resource for the human-associated viruses, which will enable the study of the role of viruses in human health. The database is freely available and can be used to study the impact of the virome on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes, such as the influence of aerosols on water cloud droplet formation. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to provide a significant contribution to the ACI community.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for the survival of life on the surface of the Earth. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is also important for the evolution of life on the surface of the Earth. This study provides a new method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide a new perspective on the regulation of K+ channels and may help us understand the physiological roles of K+ channels. (PsycINFO Database Record

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. We show that the malaria parasite uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is widely used in electronics, optics, and photonics. However, it is brittle and has a low fracture strain, which limits its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and the bandgap can be completely closed, without phonon instability. This is achieved by strain engineering, which is a promising route to tailor the properties of diamond. Our findings open up new opportunities for diamond applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies.

The impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection and may help to develop strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus outbreaks. (PsycINFO Database Record

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in a left-corner fashion, starting with the simplest elements and gradually adding more complex ones. However, there is no direct evidence that the brain performs such a merge operation. Here, we show that the activity of multiple brain areas increases with each successive word in a sentence, and decreases when words are merged into phrases. This activity is consistent with a merge operation, and provides initial evidence for a neural implementation of the merge operation postulated by linguists. Our results suggest that the brain builds syntactic structures in a left-corner fashion, starting with the simplest elements and gradually adding more complex ones. This is a fundamental property of language processing that may be important for understanding the brain’s ability to understand and produce language.

The Wnt signaling pathway is one of the most important signaling pathways in the development of animals. It is also involved in the development of cancer. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are not only similar at the protein level but also genetically redundant. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, and this differential regulation is important for tissue-specific responsiveness.

The brain circuit that promotes overeating is not well understood. Here we describe a circuit that is critical for this process. We show that stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus, which is known to induce eating, is dependent on dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta. We also show that stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus is dependent on neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the brainstem. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

The ability of plants to fix nitrogen (N2-fixation) is a key ecosystem service, but the contribution of N2-fixation to global food security is threatened by the loss of soil N2-fixing bacteria. The ability of plants to control the composition of their soil microbiota would therefore be a valuable tool for the sustainable management of soil N2-fixers. Here, we demonstrate that the production of a bacterial signal by the plant and its subsequent perception by the bacterium can be used to control the composition of the soil microbiota. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of synthetic biology in the control of the composition of the soil microbiota. This approach could be extended to other soil-dwelling organisms, including pathogens. Such a tool could be used to control the composition of the soil microbiota for the benefit of agriculture and the environment.

We show that a community-based monitoring program can reduce deforestation in the Amazon. The program was designed to overcome the limitations of remote-sensed deforestation alerts by providing communities with the ability to detect and respond to deforestation early. We show that the program was effective in reducing deforestation, but the estimated effects are imprecise because of the complexity of the program and the difficulty of measuring the effects of community-based monitoring. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. In this paper, we show that the spider can hear without ears. The spider’s web acts as an acoustic antenna, and the spider can hear the sound by sensing the motion of the web.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has killed over 500,000 people in the United States alone. The lack of a vaccine has been a major obstacle to containing the pandemic. Here we report the design of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits high-affinity antibodies. This protein can be used to design a virus-like particle vaccine that can be produced at a large scale and is expected to be cost-effective.

The development of the zebrafish is a unique model system to study the function of genes involved in the regulation of the formation of the neural crest, a transient embryonic tissue that gives rise to a variety of peripheral tissues. Here, we show that the zebrafish homolog of the ALK oncogene, DrALKals, is involved in the development of iridophores, a pigment-producing cell type of the neural crest.

The emergence of Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, is one of the most dramatic events in human history. However, the earliest stages of its evolution and ecology are poorly understood. Here, we present a large dataset of Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which is critical for understanding the emergence of plague. Our results show that the plague lineage was not present in Europe during this time, but rather it was present in the Near East and spread to Europe through rapid dispersal. This study provides a unique perspective on the early evolution and ecology of plague, and it will help us understand the impact of this disease on human history. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted men’s and women’s support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. (PsycINFO Database Record

The agricultural use of grasslands has been a major contributor to the global carbon (C) cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to crop production has led to the release of massive amounts of C to the atmosphere. This study shows that the management of grasslands can mitigate this trend and that the use of diverse, rotationally grazed pastures can be a climate-smart agricultural practice. The results of this study highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in the fight against climate change.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses from wildlife to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over to humans. We used this framework to identify the greatest risks and to prioritize the investigation of the most likely candidates. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that this resource will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular basis for the red color of nectar and may have implications for the evolution of vertebrate pollination.

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood, despite its importance for the development of the modern European population. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 450 and 750 AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of the individuals was heterogeneous, and that some of them had a genetic background that is not found in modern Europeans. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results provide insights into the genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period and suggest that complex demographic processes may have contributed to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5, were investigated. We found that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and MERS coronavirus are different. These results suggest that the capability of a virus to adapt to use human cells for cross-species transmission is a determinant of its potential to cause severe disease in humans. Thus, the capability of bat coronaviruses to adapt to use human cells for cross-species transmission may be a major factor contributing to the emergence of severe coronaviruses in humans. This study provides insights into the evolution of bat coronaviruses and the potential threat of these viruses to human health. (Show more)

This study demonstrates the utility of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) for the detection of undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which was detected in a patient before the national outbreak. This study highlights the potential of mNGS for the detection of undifferentiated febrile illness, which is a common presentation in resource-scarce settings. The ability to detect a variety of pathogens in a single test, in a resource-scarce setting, is critical for the rapid deployment of public health response. This study also demonstrates the utility of the global cloud-based platform, IDseq, for the analysis of mNGS data. This platform can be used to rapidly identify pathogens in a variety of settings, and is a valuable resource for the global community. (IDseq is available at https://idseq.org.)

The human genome is replicated in a single-stranded template mode, which is a unique feature among eukaryotes. This mode of replication is achieved by the lagging strand synthesis, which is catalyzed by the pol δ holoenzyme. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is critical for every aspect of lagging strand replication. However, the stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme has not been determined. Here, we report the stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for the single-stranded template mode of replication.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, it has been possible to synthesize simple RNA molecules, but the synthesis of more complex RNA molecules has been difficult. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of complex RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.
The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab is evaluated.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability of fungi to regulate copper content is critical for their survival in the environment and in the human body. Here we report the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for this natural product in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study demonstrates the utility of genome mining for the discovery of novel fungal natural products and the potential of these products to be used in the treatment of human disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Mars is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a high-temperature (>870 °C) phase that is not stable at present-day conditions. The discovery of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Mars has implications for the origin of the deposit and the history of the planet.

Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals, and the frequency of late-spring frosts (LSFs) is increasing in many regions. However, the geographic distribution of LSFs and the evolutionary impact of these events on plants are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of LSFs is linked to the leaf-out strategies of trees, and that the increasing frequency of LSFs in Europe and Asia is likely to cause increasing damage to the forests of these regions. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk and can inform the development of frost-resistant crops and animals.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of Th17 cells and their role in disease are not well understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can give rise to cells with a Th1 phenotype, and that this process is dependent on the expression of the transcription factor T-bet. Moreover, we show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease and that their development may be a promising target for therapeutic intervention.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, the cells that control voluntary muscle movement. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding proteins that are essential for motor neuron function. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients, which can be used to study the disease and to screen for drugs that can alleviate toxicity to motor neurons. This method will enable the study of the disease in a living patient and the rapid development of new therapies. This work will help to improve the lives of ALS patients.

The gut microbiota of ticks is a complex community that is essential for the survival of the tick and the pathogen it harbors. This study shows that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of the pathogen to colonize the tick. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how a pathogen can influence the composition of the gut microbiota to enhance colonization by the pathogen in its vector. This work also provides a framework for understanding the role of the gut microbiota in the transmission of pathogens between vectors and hosts. (Show more)

Birds with a short tail are a key component of the modern avian bauplan, but the origin of this trait is poorly understood. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery adds to our understanding of the evolution of the avian tail and the mosaic evolution of the avian skeleton.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the system without understanding the interactions between its components. In this paper, we show that the interactions between the stratosphere and troposphere are important for understanding the climate system.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and even to yellow, orange, and white. These colors are produced by pigments, which are often derived from amino acids. However, some vertebrates have distinctive colors that are not produced by pigments. These colors are produced by proteins, which are often derived from the same amino acids. We show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that the color is produced by proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is produced by the same amino acids.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence, and are thought to be dependent on the m6A modification of RNA. Here, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a breast cancer stem cell marker. We also show that ALKBH5 overexpression increases the proportion of BCSCs and decreases the tumorigenicity of breast cancer cells in vivo. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a potential therapeutic target for breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. It is also one of the most fragile. The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was easily torn. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is unknown, but the timing of the extinction, the carbon cycle changes, and the recovery dynamics are all consistent with a global environmental perturbation. This study provides a precise age model for the extinction and recovery, and demonstrates that the carbon cycle changes are not simply a result of the extinction. The age model will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and will establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. This work will also provide a critical benchmark for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Show more)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the role of RORα in the intestine is still unclear. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs and that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a new perspective on the role of RORα in the intestine and suggests that therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spike glycoprotein of the coronavirus that causes COVID-19 is a promising target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, in complex with the receptor-binding domain of ACE2, the receptor used by SARS-CoV-2 to enter host cells. We find that the spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is able to bind to ACE2 with high affinity, and that the D614G mutation in the spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is associated with an increase in the conformational flexibility of the spike protein. These results provide insights into the mechanism of action of the D614G mutation and may help to inform the design of future vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate the impact of COVID-19 on life expectancy in the United States in 2020, by race and ethnicity, and project the impact of COVID-19 on life expectancy in the United States in 2020, by race and ethnicity.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and they are the key to understanding the chemistry of compounds. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that this is consistent with the pressure-induced metallization of the elements. We also show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show that our results can be used to predict and explain the formation of unexpected compounds, and we show that our results can be used to predict and explain the formation of unexpected compounds.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its effects on climate are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of changes in global fire activity. This has implications for the carbon cycle, as well as for other ecosystem functions, and suggests that fire may be a useful tool for mitigating climate change. However, the risk of more extreme fires, especially in drylands, means that fire management must be carefully considered in the context of other land uses.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which the host controls the activity of the symbiont are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is critical for the maintenance of a symbiotic relationship between a squid and its luminescent symbiont. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, and that the catabolism of the glycan is required for the activity of the symbiont. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients may be a general mechanism by which hosts control the activity of their symbionts. This study also highlights the importance of glycans in the regulation of the symbiosis between animals and their microbes.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent topics in a large corpus of violent death narratives from the US National Violent Death Reporting System. We also identify the gender bias of our topics and show how this can be used to identify gendered patterns in the corpus. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains, and the gender bias of topics can be used to identify gendered patterns in the corpus. Our method can be extended to other domains and tasks, such as identifying topics in social media and news data. It can also be used to identify latent patterns in other types of data, such as images and videos.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague, and it has implications for the spread of infectious diseases in general.

Asteroids are a common component of the Northeast Pacific Coast ecosystem. In recent years, they have been decimated by a disease that has been linked to a virus. The virus is a member of the Parvoviridae family, which includes human parvoviruses. The virus is transmitted by contact and is highly contagious. The disease is characterized by rapid death of the host.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease with a poor prognosis. The identification of AML stem cells is of great importance for the development of more efficient therapies. We show that a monoclonal antibody targeting interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is able to target AML stem cells and that this antibody is able to suppress the proliferation of primary AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the results provide a proof of principle for the use of antibody-based therapies in the treatment of AML. Thus, the results presented here provide important information for the development of novel and more efficient therapies for AML. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean that exhibits a unique combination of cultural, linguistic, and genetic traits from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island and found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian ancestry. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the colonization happened independently from Africa and Asia. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the settlement history of Madagascar and the genetic consequences of the settlement of an island. It also provides a framework to study the genetic consequences of the settlement of other islands.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses.
