While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of new antibody-based therapeutics to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. (Read more)

Crop condition is a key indicator of agricultural production and food security. It is also a key input for agricultural decision-making, such as crop insurance and yield forecasting. However, it is difficult to obtain in real time, and is often only available at the national level. We show that the US Department of Agriculture’s Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is conducted by a large number of crop experts, can be used to monitor crop status in real time. We show that the survey data can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show that the survey data can be used to monitor crop condition and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. This work demonstrates the potential of the survey data to provide a more complete picture of agricultural production and food security, and to support agricultural decision-making.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be mediated by the brain. However, the neural basis of language is still poorly understood. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the brain’s ability to maintain information in memory. We show that the brain can maintain information in memory through changes in the excitability of single neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It also provides a framework for understanding the neural basis of language processing.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, and there is a need for a more comprehensive analysis of the response of soil respiration to warming. Here, we present the results of a global synthesis of the response of soil respiration to warming, which is the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements. Our analysis provides limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, and demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our results highlight the need for further research to understand the mechanisms underlying the observed variability in the response of soil respiration to warming. This is critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of life on Earth. The molecular signature of the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is still poorly understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the evolution of the plastid genome is a dynamic process that is shaped by the interplay of macroevolutionary events and microevolutionary processes. This model can be used to understand the molecular signature of the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle and to predict the evolutionary trajectories of the plastid genome in other organisms. This model can also be used to understand the molecular signature of the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle and to predict the evolutionary trajectories of the plastid genome in other organisms.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was caused by a combination of natural and anthropogenic factors. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the drought by a factor of five to six. This result is important because it highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also show that the drought risk will increase substantially in the future, even under a low-emission scenario. This study emphasizes the importance of considering the role of anthropogenic climate change in drought risk assessments. It also highlights the need for adaptation and mitigation efforts to reduce the risk of drought in SSA. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major scientific event of the 20th century. The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, in 1945, is a story of science, technology, and history.

(Bacterio)chlorophylls are the light-harvesting pigments of photosynthetic organisms. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of these pigments, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one from plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria, and the other from anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria. Here, we show that the two enzymes are related, and that they are evolutionarily conserved in cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, neuroinflammation-associated kinase 1 (ASK1), which is a key regulator of neuroinflammation. In this study, we found that ASK1 is required for neuroinflammation in a mouse model of multiple sclerosis, experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). We also found that ASK1 is required for the development of neuroinflammation in EAE, and ASK1 is required in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes, but not in T cells and dendritic cells. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a better understanding of the roles of glial cells in neuroinflammation. (PsycINFO Database Record

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We show that the probability of drought has increased in California over the past century, and that this increase is largely attributable to anthropogenic warming. We also show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to the exceptionally warm conditions that have been associated with the most extreme drought indicators in California.

Autism is a complex disorder with a variety of symptoms that are difficult to treat. Therefore, it is important to understand the causes of autism and to develop effective treatments. In this study, we identified a converging function of the autism-risk genes, which is the ability to activate Rac1-dependent forgetting. This function is important for behavioral flexibility, which is a core autistic symptom. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of autism and may lead to the development of effective treatments.

This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also serves to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, and mutations in the proteins that form the CRAC channel pore or the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 can cause severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify a third cause of CRAC channel dysregulation, which is associated with a syndrome of bleeding diathesis, thrombocytopenia, miosis, and tubular myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of CRAC channel dysregulation, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the ability of the aggregates to enter and accumulate within other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may help to identify potential therapeutic targets. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of bats and demonstrated that this protein, which we named Myotis pilosus (MP) toxin (MPX), inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MPX-leukotriene A4 hydrolase. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of leukotriene in the immune response of bats and the potential for leukotriene as a target for antiviral therapy. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and one of the most common genetic alterations in cancer cells is the loss of function of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. We have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and show that they block the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. We also show that SHMT inhibition is particularly effective in B-cell lines, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer cells, and a potential therapeutic target for cancer treatment.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. It is caused by a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are involved in the regulation of protein homeostasis. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a common feature of other neurodegenerative diseases. Thus, the metastable state may be a common feature of other neurodegenerative diseases. Thus, the metastable state may be a common feature of other neurodegenerative diseases.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The device can be used to study many-body physics of quantum matter, including the study of topological phases of matter, and the study of quantum phase transitions.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The study of the origin of the flowering plants is hampered by the lack of fossils, and the study of the earliest flowering plants is even more difficult because of the lack of fossils. Here we present a detailed study of the earliest flowering plant, Montsechia, and show that it was an aquatic plant, similar to Ceratophyllum, and that it is sister to Ceratophyllum.

The evolution of viruses is a key component of the history of life on Earth. However, the evolution of viruses is difficult to study, as they are usually present in very low copy numbers and are difficult to isolate. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences, which show that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. This is important for our understanding of the evolution of viruses and the history of life on Earth.

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change because it rises and falls when the weight of the atmosphere and the water column fall and rise, rise and fall, respectively, on top of changes in the volume of the oceans. We find that the rate of sea level rise has been accelerating over the last 25 y, and that this acceleration is consistent with climate change.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain is increasing with age, but that this pattern is not seen in the elderly. Instead, pain is increasing with age in midlife, and this pattern is not seen in the elderly. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this pattern continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is a key element in understanding enzyme function. However, the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is difficult to obtain by X-ray crystallography, due to the dynamic nature of the complex. Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography to obtain the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex, and use the structure to understand the reaction pathway.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the disease has a high case fatality rate. We show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is approved for use in other viral diseases, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS, and may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which the host controls the activity of the symbiont are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to control the activity of the symbiont in a symbiotic relationship between a squid and its luminescent bacterium. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, and that the catabolism of the glycan is required for the activity of the symbiont. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients may be a general mechanism by which hosts control the activity of their symbionts. This mechanism may be particularly important in the context of the dynamic changes that occur in the symbiotic relationship between hosts and their microbes during the course of the host’s life.

This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt a more empathic mindset about student misbehavior, and that this mindset can be sustained over time. It also shows that this mindset can be taught to students, and that it can be linked to positive outcomes for students. Finally, it shows that this mindset can be taught to teachers, and that it can be linked to positive outcomes for students. This work has implications for the future of schools, and for the future of our children.

DNA alkylation is one of the major causes of DNA damage and mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. Here, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcription of a lacZ reporter gene. We found that the transcription of the lacZ reporter gene is stalled at the EtdT lesions. The stalling is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop).

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia. To better understand the role of the spike (S) glycoproteins in MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the sequential cleavage of S proteins. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. (PsycINFO Database Record

This paper provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase sales of vegetarian meals. This is a simple and low-cost intervention that could be implemented in a wide range of settings, including schools, hospitals, and workplaces. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available could lead to proportional increases in vegetarian meal sales of 61.8%, 78.8%, and 40.8% in the three largest categories of meals sold in a cafeteria: hot meals, sandwiches, and salads. These proportional increases in vegetarian meal sales would be achieved with little impact on overall sales and without rebound effects. The results also suggest that the effect of increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available is largest among diners with the lowest levels of vegetarian meal selection. This suggests that the intervention may be most effective when targeting people who are least likely to make a change in their own behavior. These results provide evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail instead of going to the polls. However, there is little evidence on the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of diagnostic tests and vaccines. However, the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is unknown. Here, we report the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein ORF8, which has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may mediate immune suppression and evasion. These results provide a molecular basis for the unique properties of the SARS-CoV-2 disease and may provide targets for the development of therapeutics and vaccines. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major risk factor for cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is associated with an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia can be blocked by a CRFR1 antagonist, and that this is associated with a reduction in the expression of AQP4 and ET-1. Finally, we show that the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia is associated with an increase in the expression of AQP4 in astrocytes. These results provide a molecular understanding of the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. They also provide a potential target for the treatment of cerebral edema. (PsycINFO Database Record

We live in an era of big data. This is a good thing, because it allows us to study many different aspects of a system of interest. However, the size of the data can make it difficult to assess the significance of the results. We describe a new approach to this problem, which is based on the idea that we should set a higher bar for declaring significant the results that we find. We illustrate the approach using forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The approach can be applied to any statistical learning method. It is a general way of dealing with the challenge of selective inference.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step in the formation of blood vessels. However, the development of ECs is difficult to achieve in vitro, and the formation of blood vessels in vivo is also difficult to achieve in vivo. Therefore, the development of ECs and the formation of blood vessels in vivo are still difficult to achieve. In this study, we found that the transcription factor ETV2 can induce the development of ECs in vitro and in vivo. This study provides a new method for the development of ECs and the formation of blood vessels in vivo. It is expected to be a new method for the treatment of vascular diseases.

The identification of “orphan” receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) with oncogenic potential has led to the development of a number of targeted therapies. Here, we report the discovery of a third ligand for the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) and demonstrate that this ligand plays an important role in zebrafish pigment development. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a foundation for the development of targeted therapies for anaplastic large cell lymphoma and other diseases involving oncogenic RTKs. It also provides a model system for the study of the function of RTKs in vivo. Finally, it provides a foundation for the development of targeted therapies for anaplastic large cell lymphoma and other diseases involving oncogenic RTKs.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cell remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. (PsycINFO Database Record

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza and are suspected of causing pandemics. They have an unusual genome organization, in which the eight viral RNA segments are packaged into the virion. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments that is required for optimal viral replication. This interaction is sequence specific and not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. We propose that this interaction promotes the selective packaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. The lack of conservation of this interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides a molecular understanding of the packaging mechanism of influenza A virus and may help to prevent the emergence of new influenza strains. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is associated with the development of atherosclerotic lesions. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow is a critical factor in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerosis. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of a new therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (PsycINFO Database Record

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the natural and human landscape for millennia. However, in recent decades, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially, and the role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that human-caused wildfires disproportionately occurred in areas with higher fuel moisture. Actions to reduce the role of people in increasing wildfire activity should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We then use this method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods in five US cities from 2005 to 2015. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to measure the physical changes in any city over time. We hope that this method will be useful to urban researchers and practitioners.

Natural repellents are a group of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insects. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in insects remain unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that mediates the perception of natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in insects, and also demonstrates the evolutionary conservation of the chemosensory system in arthropods. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV is short, the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is long. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is large. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. In the case of favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, we predict a dose of 150 mg/kg given twice a day initiated at the time of infection can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load by ∼

Coral reefs are among the most diverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are threatened by a variety of human activities and climate change. One of the most severe threats is the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, which is triggered by heat stress. We show that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, which in turn contributes to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This study also highlights the importance of nutrient cycling in the early stages of heat stress and the need to consider the metabolic interactions between the host and its symbionts in the context of coral health and resilience.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the external environment. In this study, we show that the intestinal tumor model of Drosophila melanogaster leads to a dysbiotic microbiome and barrier dysfunction, which in turn promotes tumor growth. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismal lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and for developing strategies to control tumor growth. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but resistance to chemotherapy is common, and the response to chemotherapy is variable. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this expression correlates with the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft mice. Furthermore, we show that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can repress the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduce the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impair the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

The timing of the onset of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is one of the most enigmatic aspects of the last deglaciation. Here we show that the onset of deglaciation was linked to a volcanic eruption, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes that were similar to those observed today.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which is the first of its kind. We show that the majority of global catch comes from rivers with high stress levels, and that inland fisheries are particularly important for the nutrition and livelihoods of the poor. We also show that fishing pressure is highest in regions where rivers are most important for biodiversity conservation. This suggests that the conservation of river biodiversity may be at odds with the continued provision of fisheries. Our data can be used to identify areas where fisheries management is most needed to protect biodiversity and food security. This is particularly important in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors, such as water pollution and agricultural runoff. Our data can also be used to identify areas where inland fisheries are most important for food security. This is particularly important in regions where the poor are most reliant on fish for nutrition.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling cascade, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery provides a unique platform for the discovery of novel genes involved in regeneration, and it also suggests that the adult mammalian nervous system has the capacity to regenerate in a manner that is similar to the regeneration observed in C. elegans.

The process of meiosis is essential for the production of genetically diverse gametes, and the rate of recombination is a key determinant of the rate of evolution. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we compare this pattern to that in mice.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis proposes that the brain is organized into functionally distinct networks, each with its own characteristic pattern of activity. This hypothesis has been tested using functional MRI, but the results have been difficult to interpret because of the complexity of the data. Here, we show that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network, but that this RSN is subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. We also show that the dominant RSN is deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Finally, we show that the dominant RSN is associated with cognitive dysfunction in Alzheimer’s disease. These results provide a framework for understanding the organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA that regulates translation. We show that a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap, is also found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. This finding suggests that the NAD+ cap may have a role in regulating translation of specific classes of mRNA.

The epigenetic regulation of gene expression is a key mechanism in the control of the metabolic state of the cell and organism. We show that DNA methylation patterns at specific loci in blood cells of people with diabetes are altered during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT), persist for several years during the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications Study (EDIC), and are associated with glycemia. These findings support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

This study provides a deeper understanding of the role of FSIP1 in the progression of triple-negative breast cancer and the mechanisms underlying its action. The findings may aid in the design of therapies for patients with triple-negative breast cancer.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects have altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota, which may be related to the development of gut leakiness and behavioral disorders. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of the nitrogenous volatiles in the flavor of tomato fruit is unclear. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene is required for the production of a number of other volatiles, and that the gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato flavor, and will be a valuable resource for the breeding of improved varieties. (Show more)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the field. Here we use high-throughput experiments to show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the impacts of climate change on the thermal tolerance of species, and the potential for biodiversity loss to amplify the impacts of environmental warming.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to represent different aspects of the environment. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice, and we found that grid cells, which are thought to represent the local environment, are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These data suggest that grid cells might have a different organization from other cell types in MEC. This study provides a new approach to understanding the organization of neurons in MEC. It also provides a resource for future studies of the role of MEC in navigation. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a number of genes and environmental cues. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is required for flowering of the host and the parasite in a host–parasite interaction. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of the dodder Cuscuta australis illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also shows that the FT gene in dodder is not required for flowering, but is required for flowering of the host. This study provides insights into the evolution of flowering and flowering regulation. It also illustrates the importance of flowering as a signal in host–parasite interactions. This study may also have implications for the evolution of flowering in plants and flowering time control in humans.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unknown, highly unusual form of innervation of dopamine neurons by their input neurons, which we term “striosome–dendron bouquets.” These formations, which are likely to be critical to the function of the dopamine system, are found in the brains of humans and animals and are likely to be present in other species as well.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others, and we do so by reading their minds. In this study, we show that the speed at which we respond to others is a signal of how connected we feel to them. This signal is used by others to assess the quality of our connections, and it is used by us to assess the quality of our own connections.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells are specialized cardiomyocytes that are responsible for the generation of the heart rate. SAN dysfunction is a major cause of heart failure. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN function. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SAN cells and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. Moreover, STIM1 influenced SAN function by regulating ionic fluxes in SAN cells, including activation of a store-operated Ca2+ current, a reduction in L-type Ca2+ current, and enhancing the activities of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, and its beneficial effects on plant resistance against abiotic and biotic stresses have been well documented. However, the role of Si in mediating insect herbivore resistance has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by priming of the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biopesticide to protect rice against insect herbivory. Our findings may also have implications for understanding the role of Si in other plant–insect interactions. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages, as it is in the case of other ether lipid metabolizing enzymes.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by the ability to integrate information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is adaptive, and information is continuously read back into the active state of the neuron. We show that this mechanism can support memory for multiple items in working memory, and that it is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we demonstrate the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures determine the internalization efficiency and corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be of interest to the plant biology community and will help in the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for plant biology.

The world’s largest freshwater bodies are often viewed as isolated systems, but the nutrient inputs from their tributaries can have a significant impact on the health of the lake. We show that the nutrient inputs from small tributaries can be large and can be a significant contributor to the nutrient loading in the nearshore zone of large lakes. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal eutrophication and suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to include these areas.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a thermodynamic forcing that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “rare event” dynamics of many physical systems, and it suggests that the rare combinations of chemical concentrations that are required to maintain a steady state may be the result of a rare event in the evolution of the system.

This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the relationship between the brain’s electrical activity and the presence of antibodies against the NMDA receptor. This relationship is important because it explains how the presence of antibodies can cause changes in the brain’s electrical activity, which can lead to seizures. This understanding may help in the development of new treatments for this disease.

The history of carbon (C) perturbations throughout Earth’s history has been a key focus of the scientific community. However, the history of C perturbations during abrupt warming events is poorly understood. Here, we present a multiproxy approach to investigate a major C perturbation and global warming event (∼304 Ma) that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We show that the event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived C and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. Modeling indicates that the event was linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and increased nutrient fluxes during an icehouse. This work provides insights into the history of C perturbations during abrupt warming events and the potential impacts of such events on the Earth system.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme. We show that RSPO certification reduces deforestation in Indonesia, but that most certified areas contain little residual forest. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having the intended impact on reducing deforestation, and that certification is not yet having the intended impact on reducing forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection. We conclude that certification is not yet having the intended impact on reducing deforestation, and that certification is not yet having the intended impact on reducing forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection.

The exocyst complex is a large protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that can inhibit the exocytosis process in both plant and human cells. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is one of the most fundamental biological processes, yet it is still poorly understood. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics in a fish species. We find that the interplay of multiple sex determination alleles in a species can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the evolution of a new sex determination allele can produce additional axes of variation. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. This work also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics in other species. (Show more)

The retina is a unique tissue that is challenged by the presence of high levels of vitamin A and reactive oxygen species. We sought to understand the role of iron in the retina and found that iron levels impact the retina in a manner that is distinct from the effects of vitamin A. We also found that iron levels impact the health of the retina in a manner that is distinct from the effects of vitamin A. These findings have implications for the retina and other tissues challenged by high levels of vitamin A and reactive oxygen species. They also suggest that iron may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of retinal diseases.

Predators are the key to understanding the functioning of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to understanding the evolution of the food web. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is associated with morphological and functional changes throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not a dead end, but rather a stepping stone to morphological diversification and diversification of prey types. These findings help us understand the evolution of specialization and morphological diversification in predators, and the role of specialization in the functioning of ecosystems.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus. This finding has implications for the evolution of the human hand and the emergence of modern human-like tool use. It also provides a unique opportunity to compare the anatomy of the hand of a Neandertalian with that of a modern human.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and one of the most common genetic alterations in cancer is the loss of function of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. In this study, we identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it blocks tumor growth in a mouse model of colon cancer. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. Finally, we show that defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer type that is particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. These results provide a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a new class of cancer therapeutics.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated by fragmentation of natural landscapes. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results also highlight the need for more research on the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries.

Modern agriculture is a major contributor to global food production, but it comes at a cost to the environment. The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural land, but the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We also show that the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods.
